And it seems that crossed hands are correlated with 4 fingers. So it seems that nudity is correlated with 4 fingers and thus cannot be treated as an independent variable. Again, not a 100% proven fact, but the images I found are enough for a decent prior probability. It’s up to you to refute this.“Because you selected those images.”I didn’t really have to try hard to select the images, most are from the first Google Image search pages. Where the images are not nude, they still have crossed hands which seem to be correlated with 4 fingers. Where the images *are* nude, they *almost necessarily* have the crossed hands, and so there still seems to be the correlation between nakedness and 4 fingers. That is, where Jesus is naked, we expect with extremely high probability that his hands will be crossed over the genital area, and with a decent probability that they will lack thumbs.“It doesn’t really matter whether 1 in 20, 1 in 100 or 1 in 1000. art.author: skeptic
art.post: My new summary of the debate:This posting can be dismissed both on formal and on substantial grounds.1. Formal grounds:a) The author did not provide any justification for his probability estimates.b) The author did not provide any justification for treating his probabilities as independent, which can only be established through actual statistical research of the contemporary iconography.For example, there is a probable connection between nudity and 4 fingers (a nude figure will almost certainly be exhibited with crossed hands, and there is an abundance of images from different eras with crossed hands which lack thumbs; indeed, the person anointing Jesus’ body in the top image on f.28 of the Pray codex also lacks a thumb while his hand is in the position similar to that of Jesus; thus it is not proven that nudity and 4 fingers can be treated independently for the purpose of estimating probabilities).2. Substantial grounds:a) The author claims the cropping of Jesus’ feet as a significant coincidence with the Shroud of Turin, yet there are two facts that undermine this conclusion:a1) We know that as a rule medieval manuscripts had very wide margins, because the scribes knew that their books would be rebound and trimmed several times in the next  few centuries. It is thus extremely improbable that the current very narrow margins are the original margins, give or take a few mm.a2) We know that the Pray codex *was* trimmed, because it has some marginal text neatly cropped, which means that the manuscript as a whole did undergo this standard treatment.It is thus the default fact-based assumption that the original margins were a few cm wider than what we have now. This assumption must be proven false before one ascribes any significance to the cropped feet and uses them in any probability estimates.The author has failed to do this.b) The image has to be interpreted first and foremost in the light of the contemporary iconography. A comparison with other medieval manuscripts demonstrates that the bottom picture on f. 28 of the Pray codex shows three Marys standing behind the cross-adorned sarcophagus, with the angel having his feet on the lid of this same sarcophagus. The contemporary iconography allows for no other interpretation, various fishy analogies notwithstanding.c) The author’s claim that the pyramid-like pattern on the tomb lid refers to the herringbone weave pattern is false, because it looks nothing like the actual herringbone weave pattern, which looks like a series of parallel straight fish bones. Hence this alleged coincidence is also imaginary.d) The author’s claim that the tomb lid is actually the Shroud of Turin is also refuted by comparing the top and the bottom pictures on f.28: the top picture shows Jesus’ shroud, which, with its numerous folds and without any pattern, looks nothing like the rigid patterned rectangle on the bottom image.e) The author only takes into account what he thinks are convergent features, while ignoring the divergent features in his probability estimates. These divergent features include:e1) Lack of the image on the alleged shroud.e2) Lack of the actual herringbone pattern on the alleged shroud.e3) Lack of the corresponding pattern on the second half of the shroud (which is actually a depiction of the sarcophagus).e4) The different number of circles on the two alleged halves of the shroud (4 and 5).e5) Lack of wounds on Jesus’ body.e6) Jesus’ hands are crossed at the wrists (or even above them), not at all like the hands on the shroud.Conclusion: the author failed to show that his probability estimate is valid. Moreover, it has been shown that the rectangles on the bottom image of folio 28 in the Pray codex refer to the sarcophagus and its lid, not to the two halves of the shroud. The discussion about the Pray codex and its relation to the Shroud is now over.

Such numbers can only be based on actual research.The point stands.b) “The author sees no evidence for any correlation, nor for any plausible connections between discussed features.”It doesn’t matter whether author sees anything or not. Without such a justification his cropped legs cannot be any kind of a significant coincidence.The points stand.b) “As the Codex Pray is unique with its exceptional Shroud-linked features, any comparisons with contemporary iconography are baseless. The exceptions defy the rules -by definition. This is the basic logic.”Every image is unique in some respects. This does not mean that it can be interpreted outside of the light of contemporary iconography.“See above. Contemporary iconography cannot be applied for a single very specific example which may go against it.”The contemporary iconography must always be applied. The author has given no reason whatsoever for ignoring it, other than special pleading.The point stands.c) “The interpretation of zigzag pattern as an attempt (even if inaccurate) to portray herringbone pattern is fully justifiable.”There is no reason to suggest such an interpretation, other than mounting an apologetic for the Shroud of Turin – which leads to a logical vicious “circle”. In any case this cannot be proposed as one of the “coincidences” to be explained since it’s in itself at most a hypothesis which requires stretching of facts.The point stands.d) “The difference between representation of the Shroud on top and bottom pictures of f:28r is irrelevant, if one takes into account other contradictory represenations in the Codex.For example f:27 shows Jesus crucified in traditional Byzantine style implying 4 nails used, while there are only three nails on the arm of the cross hold by an angel on f:28v:”Non sequitur. The author tells us that the same object is depicted by the same author on the same page in absolutely different forms, so that it is actually unrecognizable from image to image, and he “explains” it by bringing up irrelevant and not immediately obvious minute differences in nail depictions(!). This is absurd on its face.The point stands.e) “There are no features that would exclude the hupothesis that the Shroud of Turin is referenced in the Codex Pray.”The author misses the point. Whether or not such features absolutely exclude the hypothesis is irrelevant. They do go *against* the hypothesis, lowering its probability. Thus they must be a part of the calculation, otherwise the calculation is one-sided makes no sense. Like a trial where only evidence for one side has been presented.The point stands.e1) “Lack of the image on the alleged shroud.Irrelevant. If illustrator decided not to portray the image on the Shroud for some reason, he had the right to do so. Demands of the skeptcis 800 years so about what the illustrator should and what should not have portrayed are lacking any basis.”The author’s suggestion that this most relevant point is “irrelevant” is absurd on its face. While there may be far-fetched ad hoc hypotheses that explain this state of facts, this fact does add the “negative” (i.e. against the hypothesis) probability to the wholesale count. It must be a part of the probability calculation.The point stands.e2) Same as above.e3) “The second rectangle on the lower image is irrelevant -as it is hard to interpret what it represents. I have never claimed that it has to be the other half of the Shroud.”Fair enough, although other sindonologists have generally interpreted it as the second half of the shroud.Which only leads to further problems for the author, to wit:2.1: Where is  the second half of the shroud on the image?2.2: What do the P-circles on the second rectangle represent? If they don’t represent holes, why should one assume that the L-circles represent holes? How does the presence of non-hole P-circles influence the probability that the L-circles are holes rather than ornaments?e4) The point withdrawn for this particular author. However, see e3.e5) Same as e1.e6) Point withdrawn.Conclusion: most of the points stand. 3 points are withdrawn, 2 points are added. The main conclusion stays:“the author failed to show that his probability estimate is valid. Moreover, it has been shown that the rectangles on the bottom image of folio 28 in the Pray codex refer to the sarcophagus and its lid, not to the two halves of the shroud. The discussion about the Pray codex and its relation to the Shroud is now over.”PS: See, you can do almost without ad hominems when you try. Also, I’m not a historian.
